Description

Object description

British chief engine room artificer served aboard HMS Belfast in GB coastal waters, Atlantic, Arctic and Far East, 1943-1948

Content description

REEL 1 Background in Portsmouth and Denmead, 1923-19: family; father's naval service and loss of leg; education. Period as schoolboy at Holbrook Naval School, 1935: arrival at school; pattern of education; swimming instruction; 'boxing' the compass; climbing the mast; rifle shooting; Sunday divisions; examination for naval artificer apprenticeship; discipline; organisation of school. Recollections of period as artificer apprentice at Chatham Barracks, Portsmouth Dockyard and at Torpoint, 1938-1942: problems with trade test and assignment as coppersmith; accommodation; uniform worn; documentation work during Munich Crisis, 11/1938; dispersal of apprentices to Portsmouth Dockyard, 9/1939. REEL 2 Continues: initial impressions of coppersmith shop; breakfasting in coppersmith shop; apprentice work; move to Torpoint, 1940; reaction to declaration of Second World War, 3/9/1939; work during invasion scares, 1940; belief that Germans could not invade; sight of German Air Force attacks on Plymouth; siblings role during Second World War. Recollections of operations as Chief Engine Room Artificer aboard HMS Belfast in GB coastal waters, Atlantic, Arctic and during Normandy landings, 1943-1944 : drafting to ship, 1/1943; initial impressions of ship; messing arrangements in engineering shop; overcrowded nature of ship; duties as coppersmith; use of sketches to trace ship's pipework; work in coppersmiths shop; types of pipes in ship; character of coppersmiths shop; water leakage problems. REEL 3 Continues: character of work in engine room; watch system in engine room; methods of maintaining concentration in engine rooms; degree of noise in engine rooms; duties looking after air conditioning and steering gear; problems looking after ship's fog horn/siren; working in arctic; organisation of engineering department including memories of Charles Simpson and Bill Slade; role of stokers in engine room artificers' mess; status of artificers; promotion to chief petty officer; use of hammock; his action station; patrolling in Atlantic; character of bad storm in Atlantic. REEL 4 Continues: effects of melting condensation ice in messes; atmosphere in engine rooms; conditions in Arctic; wearing of hat; communications with lanterns; method of starting boat engines in Murmansk; convoy escort duties in Arctic; commander's announcement of impending clash with Scharnhorst; atmosphere aboard ship during Battle of North Cape, 12/1943; watching gyrocompass during action; sight of Scharnhorst burning on horizon; aftermath of action; character of ship refit in South Shields, early 1944; working up in Scapa Flow; provisions carried at action stations; use of anti-flash gear; atmosphere aboard ship prior to D-Day landings; delay in D-Day operations, 5/6/1944; sight of landing craft in Channel; homing in on submarine beacon off Sword Beach; arrival off Sword Beach, D-Day, 6/6/1944; bombarding Normandy coast. REEL 5 Continues: character of bombardment; sight of landings on Sword Beach, D-Day, 6/6/1944; accuracy of bombardment; aiding in repairs to smaller ships; casualties; damage to Mulberry Harbour in storm; sight of massed bomber raid. Recollections of period as chief engine room artificer aboard HMS Belfast in Far East, 1945-1948: preparations for commission to Pacific, early 1945; move to Far East; reaction to dropping of atomic bomb; drinking regulations in Sydney; acceptance of Japanese surrender on Okinawa; entering Shanghai; state of former internees of Japanese; problems with rice wine in Shanghai; visit to Hong Kong; use of German submariner POWs aboard ship in Singapore; problem of cockroaches; dealing with humid climate; running coppersmith classes; reasons for making specialised ash trays for ship. REEL 6 Continues: visit to New Zealand; quarantine period in Hong Kong; making pin for crewman's broken leg; conversion of float from Japanese seaplane to sailing boat; Christmas celebrations, 12/1945; recreational activities on board; use of US amenity ships; shore leave in Australia; visit to Peking; move to Malaya c1947; cleaning bottom of ship in Singapore; return to GB, 1948; arrival of mail from GB; importance of privacy on board; method of sending mail from ship; lack of censorship in Pacific theatre; sitting examination in Tokyo Harbour; memories of friends Roy Fenton, Steve Barker and Victor Paine; discipline aboard; reasons for ship being a happy ship; sporting activities. REEL 7 Continues: number of crew aboard ship in Pacific; conversion of ship's hangars; advantages of billeting in mess; ship's laundry facilities; messing arrangements; issue of rum ration; opinion and character of rations; cooking in engine room in middle watch; provisions available in NAAFI; attending Sunday divisions; 'crossing the line' ceremony; attitude to naval routine of entering harbour; story of working on propeller in Iceland, 1943. Period as instructor to Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve in Newhaven, 1948-1950: volunteering for instructional duties. REEL 8 Continues: conditions in GB on return, 1948; meeting future wife; living in civilian billet; instructional duties; use of motor minesweeper. Period as chief engine room artificer aboard HMS Kenya in East Indies, 1950-1952: attitude to drafting; showing the flag in Mombasa; contrast of service aboard HMS Kenya and HMS Belfast. Aspects of leaving Royal Navy and civilian career from 1954: father's attitude to his leaving Royal Navy, 1/1954; last duties prior to leaving Royal Navy; demobilisation procedure; items kept after leaving naval service; employment at National Gas Turbine Establishment; problems adjusting to civilian life. REEL 9 Continues: subsequent civilian engineering work on naval submarine and minesweeper engines; work during Cod Wars. Reflections on service aboard HMS Belfast, 1943-1948: problems of moving swiftly through ship; Admiral Burnett trips to dentist; boiler cleaning; importance of tidiness, economy of space and tolerance aboard ship; effect of Royal Navy service; impressions of visit to New Zealand.
